story:
My Mum Yvonne sadly passed away at the age of 83 in Barnet Hospital, 14th January 2021. She will be terribly missed by her family and friends but forever in our hearts.¬†

She did not have an easy life for many reasons but did manage to keep a sense of humour through it all, although high anxiety and worry did restrict her from fully fulfilling some of her dreams.

Mum had a lifetime of pretty major medical issues. She was born with a congenital heart defect; a coarctation of the aorta (ie narrowing of the aorta) and at age 18 she had one of the first pioneering heart repair operations performed¬† by Lord Russel Brock at Harefield Hospital. She would not have survived until 21 if not for this the operation she was told.

In following years on top of several difficult personal life issues, she had yet further medical problems such as breast cancer in her 40's, a new heart valve in her 60's and heart ablation repair with pacemaker in her 70s.¬†

To this end, we feel that in remembrance of her it would be fitting to make a donation to the British Heart Foundation. Indeed, I would not be typing this now if it was not for the work of organisations such as these.

God bless Mum, sleep peacefully, lots of love and big hug. Xxxxx

story:
Dear Friends

As you know my husband Matt underwent a triple heart bypass 6 years ago. My brother in law also had stents put in to resolve his heart issues and I know others who's pacemakers enabled them to share so many more treasured years with their loved ones. So the British Heart Foundation and it's amazing work and research has had a direct impact on my family along with so many others.

Each March ( my birthday month) I try to raise money for a special cause. This year is probably going to be the biggest challenge to date!¬†

For some people the challenge is climbing a mountain or cycling through deserts. For those of you who know me well know that I absolutely LOVE chocolate!! So the thought of not having any chocolate for a whole 31 days is beyond climbing any mountain!!¬†

So if anyone fancies joining me on my Dechox Challenge or would like to support my efforts with a small financial contribution to such a worthwhile cause I would be most grateful.‚ù§Ô∏è

pageSummary: Lotts, Bel and Cleo take on Dorney Half Marathon! because In memory an amazing Dad/Husband/Brother/Friend
pageSummaryWhat: Lotts, Bel and Cleo take on Dorney Half Marathon!
story:
At the end of August last year my Dad suddenly at the age of only 51 passed away from, what we later learned, was a heart attack. My 4 siblings and I are absolutely devastated to have lost such a funny, caring, and bright Dad and continue to miss him every day. Throughout his life he participated in lots of charity work including running the London Marathon which I was very proud to watch. So, in honour of my Dad, a few of my closest friends and I will be running the Dorney Half Marathon in March to raise money for the British Heart Foundation. The Foundation works endlessly to fund research related to heart and circulatory diseases, preventing other people's loved ones from dying way too soon.¬†

It's safe to say that anyone who knows me (or Annabel for that matter) knows that running is not our strong point, and neither of us have ever ran further than a 10k before. Keeping up with our faster, more athletic friend Cleo is going to be a struggle but knowing that we're raising money for such a worthwhile cause, and in memory of an amazing Dad who was loved by so many is enough to keep us moving.¬†

¬†We will be training frequently between now and the race, documenting our progress via Strava!¬†Unfortunately due to COVID-19 no spectators are allowed on the day, however we will try and take pictures throughout, posting on our social media where we can.

We appreciate any donation big or small and your support goes to a cause close to mine, my family's¬†and many other's, hearts.

story:
Throughout February the Superdrug Skegness team will complete several challenges throughout the month for their 180 challenge, this would mean individuals will complete any activity or form of fitness relating to 180, 18 or 1.8. Whilst the store is closed it is hard for us to collect your very kind donations that go towards a fantastic charity therefore we have set up this just giving page in order to still provide a donation that could make a big difference to a family in need.

Marie Curie is the UK‚Äôs leading end of life charity. We provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement.

We‚Äôre here to support everyone in the UK through all aspects of dying, death and bereavement ‚Äì and to fight for a society where everyone¬†gets to lead the best life they can, right to the end.

We‚Äôll help you to talk, plan and prepare, to get things sorted in advance. pageSummary: I am hosting a Virtual Quiz Night to raise funds because it's 10 years since I started collecting!
pageSummaryWhat: I am hosting a Virtual Quiz Night to raise funds
pageSummaryWhy: it's 10 years since I started collecting!
story:
I've now been supporting, fundraising and collecting for Marie Curie for 10 years. A decade has passed since I did my first collection back when I was at university! That's quite unbelievable when I think back on 10 years and all I've done in that time. Ordinarily, at this time of year I'd be getting ready to sign up to take part in Great Daffodil Appeal collections.

However, as with most things at the moment, these aren't going ahead in the usual way, but I still wanted to raise funds for Great Daffodil this year, and to also mark 10 years since I started helping this amazing charity out, so I have decided to host a little Virtual Quiz night to mark the occasion!

It'll be on Friday, 12th March 2021 at 7pm on Google Meets, and I am hoping to raise ¬£200. All are welcome for the price of a donation of however much you can give to take part, whether on your own or with your family/support bubble. There will also be a prize for the winner of the quiz as well, of a ¬£20 online gift voucher!

I'm really excited to be doing this and I hope you'll all come along and join me for what promises to be an enjoyable evening that'll help raise much needed funds at what is still a crucial time for Marie Curie.

Anybody that wants to do their own 5k run/walk on Mothers Day, I‚Äôd love for you to tag me in your posts :)

I lost my Mother in November 2019. After six weeks in hospital we as a family decided the best place for her was home.

Marie Curie Nurses visited us to asses what we needed. We knew that the Marie Curie Nurses would be a support for Mami, treating her with care and patience. What we didn‚Äôt realise was how their tender consideration would also support us.

All these people who sat at her bedside were sweet reminders of a life well lived.

story:
On the 20th January, 2021 we sadly lost our beloved, Husband, Dad, Grandpa and Great-Grandpa (Pa Bob), Robert Charles Jones. He was the king of the family and was deeply loved by us all. Nothing was ever too much for Pa, he did everything he could for each of us in the family, give the best advice and made the best cheese toasties. He would also always encourage our mischief when Nan wasn‚Äôt looking and always had a cheeky smile on his face.

So as one of the grandchildren, I thought what can I do in memory of Pa and then the idea came to me. Pa loved being on boats and in his lifetime he had a number of them, us kids loved being on the boats with Pa from fishing to jumping into the sea and taking us to Lifeboat Bay when we didn‚Äôt want to walk. He was also the chairman of the local RNLI, a charity close to his heart.

With this in mind, I put my head together with my brother, Liam, we thought why not raise some money for the RNLI in memory of Pa. We thought why not walk the distance from Nan and Pa‚Äôs abode in Lichfield to their holiday home in Morfa Nefyn in North Wales, 139 miles. This bungalow meant everything to Grandpa and the whole family have great memories from the holidays we had there. As stated, the distance we will be walking locally is 139 miles (224km) sharing this distance between us with an aim to complete 122km each by the end of February.

We are going to set our target to raise at ¬£100 and all donations will be going to RNLI. In loving memory of Pa, we hope to do you proud.

All updates will be posted on Facebook and Instagram (@jonesys.journey).

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
